content.description:
Friedreich’s ataxia is an inherited disorder. Friedreich’s ataxia is caused by an insertion mutation in a noncoding portion of the <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>X</mi><mi>N</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> gene where a <math alttext="G A A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GAA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> triplet is repeated hundreds of times. The <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>X</mi><mi>N</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> gene encodes the protein frataxin. A pedigree of a family with members affected by this disorder is shown in Figure 1.

Figure 1. A pedigree of a family affected by Friedreich’s ataxia

A researcher collected <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> from several members of the family and used <math alttext="P C R" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PCR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to amplify the <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> genes from each individual’s <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The researcher then used <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gel electrophoresis to separate the <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The results are shown in Figure 2.

Figure 2. <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>X</mi><mi>N</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> gene fragment sizes for several family members. A sample of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> with fragments of known lengths was used for comparison.

The researcher also used a computer to model the structure of the mutant <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>X</mi><mi>N</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> allele. The model suggests that the repeated <math alttext="G A A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GAA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> triplets in the mutant <math alttext="F X N " overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>X</mi><mi>N</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> gene may lead to the formation of an unusual triple-stranded configuration of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (Figure 3).

Figure 3. The modeled <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></math> triple-helix structure that can form in areas with multiple <math alttext="G A A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GAA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> triplets
content.question: Which of the following types of bonds is most likely responsible for the unusual base pairing shown in Figure 3 that results in the formation of a triplex <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> structure?
